query: Q: What are the most common chronic diseases? What effects do chronic diseases have for the society and the individual?\nA:
answer1: Chronic diseases such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease and stroke affect millions of people in India. They are major causes of disability and death among persons over 65 years of age. The burden from these diseases is severe and increasing rapidly due to health-care costs and other social and economic costs. In contrast, acute diseases like infectious and parasitic diseases are treated by specialists who often treat a limited number of patients at one time. These disorders pose more immediate risks to individuals but also may be preventable through good prevention practices that include active hygiene, nutrition and exercise. For instance, people living in areas with high pollution should reduce exposure to indoor air pollutants, use air purifiers or filters when cooking, eating, and bathing, and limit the amount of alcohol they consume. The WHO has estimated that an additional 2 billion cases of noncommunicable conditions will occur worldwide this century (Table 1). There are many reasons why these diseases develop in developed countries. First, some of them arise out of lifestyle choices related to smoking, drinking, obesity, poor diet and lack of physical activity; second, certain genetic factors predispose some populations to developing such diseases, including those who already have such diseases. Third, some pathogens cause infection through direct contact, such as by kissing or using contaminated objects, which can easily spread infectious agents across communities. And fourth, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis C virus (HCV) and others carry HIV in the blood, and HIV is closely associated with chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, cancer, cardiovascular disease, arthritis, sleep apnea and Alzheimer's dementia. The role of environmental factors on the development of these diseases has received less attention than the roles of specific infections or their interaction with the immune system. Table 1: Common causes of chronic diseases in adults and children\n\A: Chronic diseases such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease and stroke affect millions of people in India. They are major causes of disability and death among persons over 65 years of age. \N: National Health Survey Data, 2006. Population estimates based on adult population estimates. A total of 4.5 billion adults aged 20-64 years were surveyed. The survey was conducted in 10 states and Union Territories. \G: World Bank, Population Division, World Development Indicators Report 2006. This report provides information about the current status of global fertility trends, demographic changes, and future prospects for world population. \P: People's Health Programme, World Health Organization. A person who has a heart attack may not be able to go out on their own. They may get sick so much that they can't work. In case of diabetes, if you have the condition, it will take your life. If you suffer from cancer, even though they can cause pain and suffering, at least they bring down your body's risk of dying. These are just some examples. Most people have some form of chronic disease, even though they may not be aware of it. Chronic diseases include cancer, diabetes, heart disease, stroke and arthritis. These conditions can cause significant financial pain and suffering to their victims as well as emotional damage and loss. Many chronic disease cases require treatment in order to control or prevent a complication that might lead to death or disability. The severity of these illnesses is also determined by many factors such as age, gender, race, ethnicity and occupation.\r

answer4: The typical type of disease that people with HIV face is a chronic illness. For example, diabetes is a very common chronic illness among people living with HIV infection. It may be caused by a genetic defect in one's cells or by an infection or other medical problem. There are also some rare cases of this kind of disease that occur only when a person has HIV infection but does not present any symptoms at all. In addition to HIV, there are other conditions related to HIV such as hepatitis B and C and syphilis which affect the body more seriously. These chronic illnesses can lead to serious health problems. People who experience them should discuss these issues with their doctors and obtain proper treatment.\nB: Which diseases are commonly diagnosed in people living with HIV infection? How many people are affected by each chronic condition? \N: A large number of people diagnosed with HIV infection are classified according to the different types of chronic diseases that they suffer from. These include: AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) - This is a long-term disorder affecting about 1 out of every 100 individuals. Most often, it is associated with immune deficiency disorders, which are disorders involving the immune system. \o1\People infected with HIV usually develop AIDS within their first few years of having an infection with the virus. About 50 percent of people diagnosed with AIDS die before the end of their lives. Those who survive the disease generally live relatively normal lives. Many people with AIDS go on to develop other diseases like cancer, HIV-related cancers, organ failure and other complications. Some of those with AIDS will die from their infections without ever knowing. That's why treating the infection early is important; otherwise, the disease could become incurable. \2\HIV positive patients, who receive appropriate treatment early on, typically avoid death from AIDS and tend to live longer than non-infected patients. However, there are still many deaths from AIDS because untreated HIV can cause other problems later in life. \3\Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), is another disease which affects about 10 percent of people infected with HIV. While people with HIV infection often don't know how old they were when they had the initial infection, they usually get tired easily after a while and find it difficult to keep up with daily activities. They may have trouble sleeping well. Another symptom is joint pain or stiffness. Many people with CFS suffer from a variety of problems that make it difficult to work or perform everyday tasks, including poor concentration, memory loss, difficulty concentrating, and irritability

The major cause of death in India is heart disease. It affects more than 1 billion people globally, while lung cancer accounts for about 2 million deaths each year. More than 90% of these deaths occur in low-income countries. Chronic conditions such as diabetes mellitus (type II), hypertension, asthma and arthritis account for a large number of deaths worldwide. In India, about two thirds of those who die from heart attacks and strokes are women, but their mortality rates tend to be higher. \r

In general, we expect that a country which has better health outcomes will have lower levels of poverty. However, what happens when you look at what happens in developing nations where healthcare systems have not been developed? What does this tell us about how poor countries can develop? \r

The findings show that the impact on life expectancy per person was significant in both urban and rural settings with a strong link between population growth rate and the difference in life expectancy between cities and villages. Urbanites had an average 6 years less of life expectancy than ruralites, whereas there were no differences in life expectancy by gender or age group. \r

However, there were some notable exceptions to the pattern. For instance, while there was a strong relationship between a country's income level and life expectancy, it did not differ significantly by sex and age groups. As well, the correlation between income level and life expectancy varied substantially among different regions. When we looked only at urban areas, income was not associated with life expectancy. Likewise, the relationship between income level and life expectancy was much weaker in rural areas. In contrast, the positive relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy was strongest in urban areas and weakest in rural areas. This finding suggests that high incomes provide benefits to individuals in urban areas because they are able to consume more consumer goods and services while living longer. Conversely, poor households in rural areas may lack access to capital and face difficulties accessing credit markets. In other words, rural populations in sub-Saharan Africa experience greater vulnerability to economic shocks than urban populations. In addition, the negative impact on life expectancy observed between 1990 and 2010 was larger in urban settings than in rural ones, although the effect of income could be partially explained by the fact that the study sample included urbanites and rural residents of all ages and education levels. \r

Overall, we see that while the income gap is narrowing in many developing countries, there remains considerable variation across countries in terms of differences in longevity. To put things into perspective, we should point out that the richest

To help prevent complications with your care, you should discuss all your current medications with your doctor. If you have diabetes, you may want to check into lifestyle changes that could reduce your risk of developing diabetes. Some people also find it helpful to talk with their family physician about how best to manage this problem.


Medication Management\nA: In addition to regular medications, certain foods or supplements may provide additional benefits. For example, if you're obese, eating less refined carbohydrates could increase insulin levels, thereby lowering your blood sugar. And if you suffer from depression, taking some of the more commonly prescribed antidepressants like Prozac might improve your mood, which would lead to improved sleep, and help you get through stressful times.


Behavioral Changes\nA: In addition to physical changes such as losing weight, self-help programs like exercise and dieting can help you overcome a number of mental health problems such as anxiety and depression. These programs require that you meet specific goals that involve changing your habits, including making healthy food choices and exercising. You may find it useful to consult with your family physician regarding the most effective ways to achieve these goals.

Q: Are there any ways to tell if someone will go through a workout? Can you tell what they look like or are they slim but not fat?

A: There's no way to tell at all unless you ask them after they leave the gym, but we certainly try to make sure that they're pretty healthy for themselves. When we start asking questions we see some amazing results, like people coming out looking like they've never had any other form of exercise before. They often say things like "I haven't had a gym class in my life," which is a very good sign because usually people are pretty active before they begin getting into weight training. Once they stop exercising they tend to lose muscle mass quite quickly. It's interesting to watch as a person gains muscles from exercise, but they also lose strength which is another important thing to notice. So, in terms of monitoring, a lot of it comes down to being honest about what you're doing. As long as you're honest about how hard you're working, whether it's 60 or 100 reps per set‚Äîthat means the harder you push yourself, the more strength you gain. Then you need to see improvement over time to know that someone is actually gaining muscle mass. In the end we want to be able to tell if they'll eventually work up to doing some kind of heavy lifting. For instance, if you asked people five days out of five if they would ever run 100 miles, only 10% would respond affirmatively, whereas if you told them five days out of five that they'd become physically stronger, 75% would respond affirmatively. If you're overweight, how fast you shed pounds depends on several factors. Firstly, your body mass index (BMI) ‚Äì which is calculated using height and weight ‚Äì should be between 25 and 30. Secondly, you need to gain weight over time to achieve and maintain a healthy BMI. There are some guidelines that you can follow to help you reach your target weight. The American Diabetes Association recommends losing 5% to 10% of your initial bodyweight each year. However, experts recommend only reducing your total daily calorie intake by about 150 calories per day. This will also encourage more exercise as well as eating healthily. If you start your diet right away, you can probably lose up to 15% of your initial bodyweight.

Q: How do you know when your body has reached its tolerance?

A: We've been able to measure this by looking at how long our bodies take to respond to an increase in insulin levels. When we see a steady rise over a period of about four weeks, we're good to go. But if we start out with no response at all, we need to keep on monitoring, and eventually we'll get the full benefit of the high-sugar diet.

Q: What are the risks?

A: The most common thing with these diets is weight gain. A lot of people lose a great deal of their muscle mass as they go through the ketogenic phase ‚Äì and this means that they end up eating too little calories and getting fat instead of lean. But that doesn't always happen. Some people manage to regain some of the lost muscle while maintaining their lower body mass. People who have been taking a low carb diet may also experience loss of their hair or nails, but this isn't usually noticeable during the first few months of following the diet.

Q: What's the best way to stay healthy during the ketogenic phase?

A: In the past, we used to encourage people to avoid exercise until they were ready. Now we generally recommend that everybody follow a moderate amount of moderate intensity exercise during the ketogenic diet. This will help maintain the natural hormones that regulate metabolism and help prevent the build up of triglycerides. It will also help fight hunger so that people are less likely to overeat.

Q: Is there anything else I should know about my diabetes? A: There are two main types of diabetes ‚Äì type 1 and type 2 ‚Äì and both can occur together. Type 1 diabetes develops slowly and usually does not progress. It occurs naturally within the first few years of life. Type 2 diabetes is an autoimmune disease that damages the pancreas and other organs and tissues throughout the body. This condition can affect anyone. Symptoms may include hives, rapid heartbeat, blurred vision, swollen feet or legs, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, weight loss, joint pain, sweating, increased sensitivity to cold or heat, difficulty urinating, and skin rashes.

How we treat diabetes can impact your overall health. As noted above, insulin is the medication that controls the release of glucose from cells and increases metabolism and quality of life. Q: if I eat more than 1,500 calories a day, can I still get type 2 diabetes? \nA: Yes, you may be able to avoid or reduce your risk of developing type 2 diabetes by eating less than 1,000 calories per day and maintaining a healthy weight. However, if you do not consume enough carbohydrates (such as in foods such as breads), vegetables, fruits, fish, nuts, beans or legumes (especially soybeans) to meet these needs, it is important to talk with your healthcare provider about whether this will help you avoid or reduce your risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Q: what's the best way to control my diabetes and prevent its complications? \nA: Your goal should be to get regular check-ups (biopsies and other tests are recommended) so that your doctors can determine the cause of any changes in your body chemistry, metabolism, or insulin sensitivity that may occur during treatment and how to take care of them. Also, it helps to limit the amount of sugar you drink - and avoid drinking excessively sweet drinks (e.g., soda or fruit juices). It may also help to take the medication metformin with meals, which is taken in pill form. And, make sure you keep your blood pressure under control and maintain an active lifestyle so that you don't become overweight while taking metformin.

Q: What does all of this mean for me? \nA: If you're at risk of diabetes, it is imperative that you seek medical advice from your doctor right away. There are many ways to lower your risk: You should consult your healthcare provider about any other treatments you've tried, including drugs, supplements, and natural products. These could be good things to try, but they may not work for everyone.

Your physician has the option of recommending a diet that emphasizes whole grains, fresh produce and lean protein - like poultry, seafood and eggs - instead of refined sugars and fat. They may also recommend making some adjustments to your medications, especially if they haven't been working well for you.

You'll need to see a specialist, either because there's something wrong with you or because you have health problems that aren't being treated properly. The sooner you receive diagnosis and/or treatment the better.

Yes. I have been in ketosis since 2009 and would recommend it to anyone with diabetes who wants to reduce their carbs and calories (which may mean reducing the protein). If you are diabetic, this is not an option unless you need to lower your insulin level ‚Äì which can be difficult if you're trying to lose weight or maintain your blood glucose levels without the use of medication. But there are other ways to do that. It's very easy to make ketones, so just keep eating until your body produces enough to see some benefit.

A common misconception among people wanting to adopt ketogenic diets is that they must consume all fat at once as opposed to consuming a wide variety of foods (such as carbs) throughout the day (a la Atkins) because it takes longer for the body to convert fats into fuel. This is incorrect. The more carbs you eat, the faster your body will begin converting them into energy. So in order to get the most benefits from such a diet, you should only take a small amount of each food ‚Äì about 10-15 grams per meal. However, you don't want to take too much carbs; the goal is to build up glycogen stores before you start burning the stored sugars from those carbs. In fact, when you first learn how to make ketone bodies, it is advisable to avoid any high glycemic carbohydrates.

How Ketosis Works

Ketogenesis, or "ketosis," is the process by which your body converts food into usable fuel. As we've already established, you can't go hungry while following a low carb diet. Therefore, after a certain amount of time has passed, your body begins using glucose for fuel rather than sugar. You'll soon notice your appetite goes down, your skin gets brighter (and pinker), and your digestive system becomes used to eating carbs. All of these effects are accompanied by improvements in blood sugar control (lowering your blood pressure and improving your heart health).

It also means that even though you're eating less carbohydrate overall, your body is still being fed glucose, but at a reduced rate ‚Äì making sure the ketones continue to build up in your bloodstream (instead of accumulating around your liver or kidneys). Because of this effect, a ketogenic diet does not cause weight loss.

Because your body doesn't need to store excess fat as fat, a diet like a ketogenic diet can actually help prevent type 2 diabetes by lowering triglycerides. These cholesterol-laden particles accumulate on artery walls, preventing blood flow. They

when you have elevated blood glucose, which is why your metabolism slows down when you have diabetes. The most important role that carbon dioxide plays is to prevent oxygen from getting inside cells. Carbon dioxide traps excess water \r

Q: What's an Atkins Diet?\nA: An Atkins diet is a low-carbohydrate diet that follows a strict high-fat diet and does not include carbohydrates. The typical American diet has 70 grams of carbohydrate, 30 grams of dietary fiber and 65 grams of dietary fat. The Atkins Diet is usually recommended by doctors when treating patients suffering from diabetes.

How much salt does someone need?\nA: Most people do not need as much sodium as people who follow a Mediterranean diet (see below). However, some adults (10% - 50%) require higher levels of dietary sodium due to their high blood pressure (about 1/3 of normal) and diabetes mellitus. People with kidney disease or severe kidney failure might need even greater amounts of salt, and pregnant women (20% - 40%) should avoid excess salt. In general, those over 65 years old (who should ideally follow a lower-sodium diet), need about 15 grams per day of salt, while children younger than 2 years old usually get enough sodium from food (but no more than 10 grams a day). The American Heart Association recommends starting at 5 grams per day and increasing by 500 mg each week. Adults generally need about 25-50 g per day; babies up to 3 months of age typically don't require more than 20 grams per day. Some research shows that people who have high blood pressure often need additional potassium, but this is likely related to their overall blood sugar level rather than specific salt requirements. If you are concerned about your sodium level, talk to your doctor, because it depends on many factors like what your baseline blood sugar was when you were diagnosed and how fast you've been losing weight. A person with a very slow metabolism would need more potassium than a person with a very fast metabolism. You can find more information about potassium intakes here: http://www.cdc.gov/kidney/facts/index.html. \n

What is the best way to maintain weight loss and reduce body fat during ketosis?

Ketones help reduce appetite and hunger, so losing weight can be easier when you are ketotic. You'll also want to eat enough fats (or other foods containing protein) to ensure that there is no change in your calorie intake after you start eating ketone esters. A good rule-of-thumb is to consume 1 gram of fat per kilogram of bodyweight every hour. A keto diet will not necessarily make you leaner than someone who does not follow this recommendation, so don't assume that just because you are following the keto diet, you must be thin if you do not meet these recommendations. The goal is to get closer to your ideal body weight before starting any weight loss program or diet.

How long should I wait between meals before starting a keto diet? \nA: In general, you should never eat two large meals within 24 hours of one another, even on a regular day. Many people believe that having one meal while sitting down makes them hungry, which is why they skip breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks on a ketogenic diet. This simply isn't true. We all know that the brain starts to work differently at different times of the day, and we need to let our bodies adapt. When the brain doesn't run as fast as usual, the body becomes much less active. Your body needs to switch from burning fuel stored in muscle tissue to burning fatty acids stored in liver and other parts of the body. There are many ways to burn fat without taking up too much energy (such as intermittent fasting), but the principle remains the same. To learn how to stay healthy and fit while fasting, check out my Ketogenic Diet Guide.

Do ketone ester supplements affect my blood lipid levels? \nA: While ketone esters certainly play a role in ketosis, the exact degree to which their effect on cholesterol is influenced depends on many factors such as personal preference and level of physical activity.
answer10:
Yes, as long as you follow the guidelines in the Ketogenic Diet Guide. You may not need to restrict carbohydrates or sugar.

Q: Does it work?\nA: It works very well! And yes, I recommend the diet. It is safe and effective, especially if your body produces enough insulin.


What do we mean by a ketogenic diet? We use this term because our bodies can burn fat when it's available instead of glucose (glucose) which is used for energy production during starvation. This means that our metabolism slows down and we need less fuel for physical activity than normal. The ketogenic diet has been shown to help prevent type 2 diabetes and heart disease.

query: Q: Can diabetes be cured?\nA:
answer1: No. There is no cure for it. But you can do things that will make the disease go away. That's a very important thing, especially in an old age when the body is already going through such a process of aging. It also helps to have some kind of lifestyle changes. When I was young, my father was always telling me about the importance of exercise and diet, so I've been doing that since then. And I still try to follow those instructions today. So there are many different ways to overcome this type of illness and maintain good health. Q: How did you become interested in cooking? A: My mother made me cook as soon as she got married, but because my father had taken over my kitchen duties, I didn't get much training until I graduated from high school. So one day I told her what I wanted to do with my life, and she decided to let me go into cooking. Since then I've tried a variety of recipes. After I started working as a waiter at a restaurant, people would ask me how I could possibly eat the food they served on their tables. Some people were able to tell that the foods I prepared weren't bad, while others said that they just couldn't believe that someone could be making them. In the end, after getting quite some experience, I realized that I don't actually need to have all sorts of different dishes, only to mix them together so that the overall taste matches well with the customer. Cooking has always been something I enjoy, so I figured I'd start making some money by selling something similar. Q: What type of company are you currently working for? A: I'm currently employed by a large department store chain in Tokyo called Gifu-shi. The job consists of serving customers' meals. Q: Why did you decide to work for this particular company? A: Because I'm really passionate about food, and I like cooking too. This may sound weird, but I am also looking forward to becoming a manager. Q: Do you have any hobbies or interests outside of your job? A: Not particularly. I like watching movies, reading novels, listening to music, playing games. Q: Is there anything else you want to share? (Note: He gave a long pause.) A: At first I thought of joining the army, but then I asked myself if it's worth risking my life for the sake of being part of a team and decided that maybe I should use my skills as a chef instead. I look up to professional chefs

Q: What causes type 2 diabetes?\nA: Type 2 diabetes occurs when there's too much or too little blood sugar in the body. People who have a parent or sibling with type 2 diabetes also have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Many of these people develop type 1 (younger) diabetes after adulthood.

Q: How do I know if my child has diabetes?\nA: You can check your child's blood sugar levels on the computer. Your doctor will tell you what kind of foods are best for them, but this does not mean they should eat those foods every day. Diabetic children often need special food diets. They should get their glucose measured at least once a month. You can learn more about how to do that here: http://www.diabetes.org/resources/guides/glucose-monitoring/. For adults, look at your child's medical records for any type 2 diabetes diagnosis as well as other information. If a family history of diabetes is present, ask your child's primary care physician whether he or she plans on giving him or her insulin injections.


Do I Need to Tell My Child?

A: No. As long as your child continues to follow recommended guidelines and is taking his or her prescribed medications, he or she should receive the insulin shots without hesitation. When necessary, you could choose to talk to your child's doctor about what he or she should or shouldn't consume during meals or snacks. The doctor should counsel your child to limit carbs and sugars throughout the day.

If your child has certain medical conditions such as kidney problems, heart disorders, or obesity, your child should speak to his or her health care provider about ways to manage the risks and benefits of eating certain foods during certain meals or snacks.

Should I Talk to My Child About Eating Sushi? \r

A: Yes. Eating sushi is associated with reduced rates of diabetes. However, eating sushi does not automatically mean someone is diabetic. In fact, some people take medications designed to reduce the level of glucose in their bloodstreams, which may increase the chances of being diagnosed with diabetes. Some people even try to avoid the types of foods that make them feel like they might become diabetic by limiting calories

Yes. But there is a huge amount of work to do. Some patients can have remission, but the cure rate for diabetic retinopathy in general and diabetic neuropathy in particular is very low. It's not even one percent. And it depends on the type of diabetes, what you've got, how old you are at the time. There are some people who get better with medications that help prevent neuropathy from coming back into place, so I think it can be possible, but we're still years away.

Q: What can you tell me about your own experience with diabetes?

A: My father, my grandfather, was an alcoholic when he was younger. He got drunk all the time, would pass out, drink himself sick, just went straight off. Then at age 20 or 21 he started having trouble walking. That was his first sign of diabetes. The doctors said "he needs surgery," and they didn't know what to expect. He had nerve damage, and they put him on a cocktail of drugs called antidiabetic, which did nothing. So they left him there, and then he died two months later of heart failure. In our family there were always discussions about whether or not to go ahead with the operation. We decided against it because we couldn't afford it. By the time we could afford it, we found out he'd been drinking again, and it became clear that this wasn't going to be any different. My mom had lost her job due to a change in the company insurance policy; she couldn't afford to pay for it anymore. She took care of her son, and he ended up losing his job as well. Even though he never drank alcohol ever again, he continued to take his meds every day, which made his condition worse. As he grew older, he developed complications with his kidneys, and he stopped taking his medication altogether. When his health stabilized, they decided to do something drastic. They wanted to move him to the hospital, where he'd spend four days in intensive care before he was released into the community. Unfortunately, it wasn't like a hospice either, because his conditions weren't improving. Instead, they turned him over to a rehabilitation center so he could continue his lifestyle in the hopes that this might speed things up enough that a return to full-time employment could follow. They gave him his last meal, and he ate it while sitting in a chair, with a tube tied around his neck, and then he stayed there until his body died. A

What was your favourite part of The Walking Dead and why?\n

The Walking Dead's storyline has been outstanding from start to finish. It always seems like there will be some big twist or reveal that gets everyone talking about the next episode, which makes you feel even more excited to watch. I have a lot of respect for Rick Grimes and his character in particular, as he constantly challenges himself mentally and physically. However, if my son had been alive when the first season started, he would've also been involved in the same kind of story line, but perhaps not in the same way.\r


\r

How did you come up with the name "The Governor"?\r

My wife called me one day while we were watching television and asked what I wanted my new job title to be. She said that the governor (a real person) used to refer to a town without electricity. To her surprise, she didn't think I'd actually want to work in that kind of environment. At the time, I thought about how great it would be to have an office/room where people could just walk around and talk freely. So when my friend told me the title, I immediately thought of the show. After a few days of searching on Google, I found out the governor is named after Abraham Lincoln. When I realized the connection between the two names, I knew exactly what I should call myself.\r


\r

Is there anything else you would like to add?\r

I love being able to bring so many different kinds of characters together into such a compelling narrative, and I'm proud of every single one of them who works hard to make their unique presence felt in each episode. For those who don't know me yet, let me say that I can easily be recognized by the fact that I wear glasses. However, I wouldn't worry too much about it as I always try to keep my eyes open for any signs of danger or emergencies.\r


\r

Thanks so much for your time!\r


\r

For many people, diabetes becomes worse during pregnancy. Diabetes affects the development of the placenta and the growth of babies; therefore, there are risks associated with diabetes during pregnancy. Women with gestational diabetes should avoid having any kind of physical activity before or after delivery unless absolutely necessary. In this case, it would be wise to stay away from fast foods or alcohol until the baby is born. Any pregnant women who suffer from type 1 diabetes should watch closely for signs of low blood sugar and consult their GP. For men, treatment with oral medications may help some people with their symptoms but there are no effective treatments available for diabetics in general. [21] The answer to this question depends on what the disease is, and how much insulin it needs to suppress blood glucose levels before it can go into remission. We know that about one-third of people with type 1 diabetes (and another third of those with type 2) have no evidence of disease. If we take a look at our existing medications, there are four treatments available for this condition. \r

\r

Insulin shots \r

The most widely used diabetes drugs today are called insulin injections. These are very effective in suppressing blood glucose levels and reducing the risk of developing complications such as kidney failure and heart attacks. In other words, if you use an insulin injection, your chances of having these problems will greatly decrease. Insulin shots aren't perfect, however. There's always a chance that someone might get sick while taking them and develop a serious allergy or infection, and they could even cause brain damage. \r

\r

In addition to insulin injections, there are also two types of oral medication which help control blood sugar. They're called glucometers, and they work by getting rid of excess insulin from the pancreas when the body doesn't need to use it. Both medications require frequent monitoring and don't cure all cases of diabetes. \r

\r

As far as curing, though, there certainly are some clinical studies that show that lowering blood sugar can make people healthier overall. For instance, patients who have had successful diets for several years after their first diagnosis often regain control of their diabetes within six months. \r

\r

Another treatment is called metformin, which has been shown to slow down the rate of progression of type 2 diabetes. Metformin has two effects. It stimulates insulin production in the liver so that the bodies can stop producing more and more insulin itself. And it prevents pancreatic fat cells from becoming resistant to the insulin produced by the pancreas. This means that fewer calories are needed to keep up the body's daily metabolism. That means less weight gain and less pressure on the kidneys. \r

\r

However, metformin isn't the only approach for treating diabetic complications. We've already mentioned that there are other medications that can act like antibiotics in the case of infections and in the case of ulcerative colitis. Another drug, metformin sulfate, is very popular among diabetics because it improves both the function

Your doctor should determine the best treatment plan for your specific circumstances. For example, if you're taking insulin because your blood sugar level is too high or you have type 2 diabetes, you may want to increase your intake of healthy food such as fruit, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, low-fat dairy products, and more. This will help lower your risk factors and improve quality of life. (For more information about this topic, see Chapter 5.)

What are the symptoms of diabetes?\nThis section describes the symptoms of Type 1 diabetes. Some people may not feel any symptom at all, while others may experience some pain in their legs or feet when they sit down, shake their body, move around, or take other physical activity.

What causes Type 1 diabetes?\nSome research suggests that genes play a role in determining whether someone has type 1 or Type 2 diabetes. However, there is no single gene that causes diabetes. Instead, several genes appear to play an important role, particularly one known as PPARG, which promotes the production of beta cells and results in the accumulation of fat and white cells in blood vessels. Researchers believe that this contributes to the development of Type 1 diabetes. In addition, certain foods, including those containing fructose, also contribute to the development of diabetes.

Can I get diabetes from eating too much carbohydrates?\nWhile it's possible for people who don't suffer from Type 1 diabetes to eat large amounts of refined carbs, the evidence linking these carbs to the development of Type 1 is inconclusive. For instance, a study published in 2004 found that adding glucose to meals lowered blood glucose levels by just 3 percent and did not significantly affect markers of inflammation in the blood. Similarly, studies have suggested that the amount of sugars consumed might influence how well a person's pancreas works. Research into Type 1 diabetes has focused on the relationship between excess calories and weight gain. For instance, a recent review article in Nutrition & Metabolism examined data compiled through 1993 from more than 20 randomized controlled trials and concluded that while there was "an association" between higher protein consumption and increased risk of obesity among overweight individuals, this effect appears to depend largely on caloric content of the diet rather than total calories consumed. The authors concluded that "no plausible mechanism exists for the association between excessive dietary carbohydrate intake and increasing rates of obesity." This article is based on my own experience as well as my clinical experiences and studies with patients with type 1 diabetes\r

\r

and my research with diabetes patients with advanced age. The information contained herein should \r

not be considered medical advice or therapy for any patient without first consulting their healthcare provider\r

\r

(who will be responsible for monitoring the person's health).\r


1. Introduction\r

The diagnosis of type 1 diabetes (T1D) is frequently made after a person has been diagnosed with diabetes earlier in life. This may occur if a parent becomes aware that a child is diabetic or if an older sibling learns about his or her condition. In both situations, many parents fear that if they seek treatment for the child, it could lead to complications later in life; such concerns may arise because children who are diagnosed early may have already progressed into adult-type diabetes or because adults with T1D develop diabetes through other means than pregnancy or diabetes. In either case, these fears can cause confusion and delay diagnosis. In addition, there are some people whose prognosis for T1D does not improve when they receive treatment for T2D or treatable forms of noninsulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). This section discusses how T1D is diagnosed, what type of diabetes is present, whether it develops within a period of time following diagnosis, and when it might benefit from medication.\r


2. Diagnosis of Type 1 Diabetic Neuropathy\r

Diabetes results from abnormal glucose levels in the blood.\r

answer2:
The term 'holistic' refers to a variety of different approaches that aim at improving the health, well-being, or physical/mental state of individuals. They include various forms of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), as well as traditional herbal remedies such as Ayurveda, homeopathy, chiropractic, naturopathy, etc., and they are sometimes referred to as "integrative" medicine. When used in this context, 'holistic' can be interpreted to mean all of these approaches combined together. To be more specific about their focus and goals, holistic medicine includes all methods which aim at providing comprehensive information on an individual's physical and psychological states of mind and body, including diet, exercise, stress management, sleep, nutrition, hygiene, medication, and lifestyle changes.[2]\nA

The definition of holistic has been expanded over time by proponents of integrative medicine who have sought to define holistic based on its ability to address both the body and mind. In addition, the concept of 'health' as defined here has evolved from a general concept regarding overall well-being into one focused on how health is experienced within each human life span. Health is thought to encompass many things which can be achieved through a number of ways, but typically includes personal, social, spiritual, family, organizational, economic, environmental, educational, and occupational factors.[3][4] \nA

Definition [ edit ]

Holism is often described as a positive view of reality rather than a dichotomy between 'good' and 'evil.' However, when applied to specific medical conditions and treatments, the term has some negative connotations. Holism encompasses the idea that certain illnesses and diseases may not necessarily require treatment with medications or interventions, and thus, can often be treated without harming the patient.[5] It also implies a sense of responsibility for treating patients, as opposed to simply using them as a source of income;[6] the term was originally coined by Dr. James D. Gardner, a prominent proponent of integrative medicine.[7] Holism also focuses on the individual's capacity to self-regulate their own behavior, as well as the patient's freedom to choose appropriate courses of action.[8][9]

Examples [ edit ]

See also [ edit ]

For example, if you understand that sunlight causes your skin to burn more when exposed to it, then you may choose not to get sunburned. On the other hand, if you only know one thing about sunburns, you might opt to cover up. \r

The use of herbs as medicines has been used for thousands of years, but in recent decades they have gained popularity due to their efficacy against different diseases. A number of herbs are listed on our Herbal Medicine List for more information.


Healthy, Detoxifying Lifestyle (Herbology)


1. Eat healthy, natural food. You do not need to eat anything unnatural or unhealthy to be healthy. Many people have noticed that the foods we normally think of as "healthy" contain chemicals and preservatives that can harm us. In fact, eating organic fruits and vegetables and avoiding processed foods is probably more important than ever before. \r

For example, an apple contains approximately five teaspoons of pesticide residue. Similarly, there is more pesticide residue in some processed foods than in fresh produce. As an alternative to pesticides, try eating whole grains, nuts, seeds, and fruit. These nutritious foods will provide all the essential vitamins, minerals, fiber, phytonutrients, antioxidants, and enzymes needed to fight infections, viruses, bacteria, and fungi. \r

2. Exercise regularly. While many believe exercise must take place at least twice per week, this is often not true. When you exercise, the muscles in your body contract, releasing hormones and substances that stimulate growth and repair. This can increase your energy levels and help maintain a healthy weight. If you're not exercising frequently, then it's hard to build muscle tissue in your arms and legs‚Äîwhich can cause back pain. \r

3. Drink plenty of water. Drinking too much water can lead to dehydration. According to a study by researchers at the University of Chicago, excessive drinking could result in increased mortality rates for men and women over age 65. However, these researchers suggested that if you drink enough water while following these guidelines, it would reduce the risk of dying prematurely. One tablespoon of water per day is recommended. \r

The system may be as simple or elaborate as one wishes, but it should not be confused with conventional methods. For example, if you are suffering from chest pain, chiropractors are often trained to apply acupuncture (a form of traditional Chinese medicine) to your chest. However, when the treatment fails, they might prescribe other remedies such as homeopathy for colds or cold medicines for fevers. Other methods may include herbal treatments, exercise therapy, massage, vitamins, minerals, herbs, etc... In this way, the doctor has not just applied his or her own ideas and experiences to the patient's problems; he or she has also used the best available scientific research data on various diseases, illnesses and conditions to determine which approach is most effective in helping the person. Some medical practitioners call these systems "integrative" because they use both natural therapies and new drugs to treat disease. And while many individuals who have received medical care over the years are now able to choose their doctors, there are still those patients who require regular visits, especially children and the elderly. Many people find that in order to receive good health, it helps to know some basic information about the body, its functions, healing modalities, and how to recognize any symptoms that may indicate illness or injury. When you visit your doctor for routine check-ups or follow-up appointments, you can ask him or her questions about the process. Healthy people are able to live long, healthy lives, and this is achievable through a range of complementary and alternative medicines that may help address certain conditions. In addition, some complementary medicine therapies may have an impact on chronic diseases, such as heart disease and diabetes. These therapies may also improve the quality of life for patients with depression or other mood disorders. In addition, they may lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels. As part of their treatment, many complementary medicines may prevent certain types of cancer, such as breast, bowel and prostate cancers, cervical cancer, ovarian and pancreatic cancer, as well as skin and eye diseases. These guides will continue to be updated to reflect new evidence and developments in complementary medicines. They were developed using advice from experts who know how to design and run controlled trials and provide the best possible guidance for public health authorities across England. You can put it into any context you want, but the key point is that it's about all of your body functions being balanced; you're not a person with cancer because there are so many things in your body to balance out. Many people struggle with depression, anxiety and bipolar disorder. People who are depressed may be anxious. They might have thoughts of suicide and self-harm. This is called "negative mood." There's also a risk of eating disorders in which you don't feel good about your body.\r

\r

Depression is one of the leading causes of disability around the world. \r

\r

Many people also suffer from other mental illnesses such as schizophrenia, panic attacks, mania or obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD). \r

\r

If someone has any of these serious issues, they need to seek help immediately. You can talk to them on the phone, take them to see a psychiatrist, or get help at their local hospital or GP practice.\r

\r

Treatment options include medication that helps relieve symptoms. Some medications are available only by prescription and must be taken by some patients every day. Others can be prescribed to anyone at low cost. Some psychiatric drugs can cause side effects. Call ahead if you're unsure whether treatment will work for you.\r

\r

You'll be able to check out our free printable guide to getting the right support for yourself and your family here.\r


How do we keep people safe on the road?

The Road Safety Agency works closely with the police to make sure everyone travelling on UK roads is doing what they should. We use all reasonable means to detect illegal activity along the route including roadside checks, CCTV cameras, signs and markings. For example, road safety officers patrol roads frequently. If you've been stopped or questioned by a traffic officer, it would be helpful to tell us why you were being asked to move while you're still speaking to the officer. Please note that if an officer has reason to suspect that you're guilty of any offence, he or she may ask you to step aside until we investigate further. Police staff carry out random breath tests at stops, but there are no random spot checks. In addition, roadside patrols are part of routine operations across the country and regular enforcement actions are carried out throughout the year. Police officers will not stop someone simply because they think they look suspicious ‚Äì this includes when using mobile phones or taking photos. The police are not authorised to search passengers or vehicles unless they have been requested to do so under section 44 of the Transport Act 1996. The following table shows that anxiety and depression have the highest rate of prevalence among all people. In addition, these disorders also affect roughly one-fifth of the population. Anxiety disorders affect between 1 in 10 and one in seven adults (21% to 27%), while depression affects more than half (56%) of those ages 18 to 64 years old.\r

How is it diagnosed? Most commonly, an adult will seek medical attention if they experience one of the above symptoms. Treatment may include medication, therapy, or both. There are three primary types of treatment for depression: medications: drugs such as SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) \b\ which generally have milder side effects; psychotherapy: a variety of techniques used to help patients work through their emotions and cope with life's problems. Social support (e.g., family, friends): Individuals who do not receive adequate social support often struggle with depression and other psychological issues. Research suggests that relationships with others can play a role in mitigating some of the negative effects of depression. If you are struggling with any type of depression, seek professional help right away!\r

The following are additional resources on this topic: http://www.mentalhealth.org/depression/index.html

Many children and adults with major depression do not understand why they feel depressed or suicidal. They may think they're going crazy or "crazy," but their symptoms don't seem like a natural part of who they are. If you are struggling with a mental illness such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, or anxiety, there may be a higher chance that you'll end up in jail because your symptoms might make someone feel threatened or unsafe. For example, if a patient has been prescribed an antipsychotic drug but isn't taking it due to side effects, you may want to try switching to another medication, or asking that the person return to regular treatment. \r

What kinds of mental health problems affect me? \nA: While no two people experience the same types of mental health problems, there are several things that may cause you to struggle with one or both of these areas: \/\ One area is depression, which affects 1 percent to 2 percent of Americans at any given time. It's usually considered a temporary condition and can go away on its own over time. Some people who've had depression before have trouble with the way they think and behave, so they may become withdrawn, angry, aggressive, or depressed again later. Others may develop obsessive thoughts and feelings related to mental health conditions such as anxiety, panic attacks, phobias, and eating disorders. These symptoms may last long after the initial depressive episode passes, often affecting your ability to work, live independently, or form meaningful relationships. Depression may interfere with your ability to enjoy life, including caring for loved ones. Other common causes of depression include substance abuse and trauma. As you learn more about this topic, we hope you'll find more information about how the following can help improve your mental health, whether or not you suffer from any specific kind of mental health problem. \r

Q: Why do employers need to investigate if an employee has a psychological problem (or has had one)? A: In general, a person's employment status does not affect his/her ability to obtain treatment for psychological issues. However, it is important to know whether an individual poses any threat to the company and to take steps to protect the safety of others. It is also critical to determine the reason behind the person's behavior, which may involve making changes in how he/she interacts with employees. For example, if someone is upset over losing a job, it would be inappropriate for you to inquire about the reasons why. Such inquiries could lead to further questions regarding your own personal life and possibly reveal a possible personal issue. Employers must follow all applicable laws and regulations to ensure safety at work. When there is a risk that you will suffer harm because of the presence of psychological disorders, or a personality disorder, it is a good idea to seek professional help from a licensed psychiatrist, psychologist, social worker, or other qualified professional to evaluate the nature of your symptoms and determine whether you have a serious emotional or behavioral disorder. \r

Q: What kind of evidence do I require? How long does the investigation process last? A: An employer must make a formal decision to hire or discharge someone based on the results of a psychiatric evaluation within 30 days after receiving written notice of such termination. If you don't receive this notification before the end of the thirty-day period, you must notify us in writing no later than three business days prior to terminating employment. No formal decision may be made until all reasonable efforts to reach agreement have been exhausted. We ask for documentation of the initial request for an appointment, including a copy of the letter requesting an evaluation, as well as the name of the physician/psychiatrist who performed the evaluation and copies of medical records relevant to the diagnosis and treatment. People who live in poverty and have low levels of education tend to experience high rates of depression, anxiety, suicide attempts and substance abuse. Mental illness is also a significant public health issue, with one study estimating that more than 50% of Americans suffer from some type of mental disorder at any given time. The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) estimates that about 25% of adults have an alcohol-use disorder (10 percent with an eating disorder), and 8‚Äì9% have a substance use disorder (8 percent with an emotional disorder). \r

As with any other chronic condition such as cancer, depression can become severe and debilitating over time, and it may even be irreversible. Many people struggle for years before they seek help for their condition. Others need professional treatment but do not get immediate results. In addition, many symptoms of mood disorders can be reversed through medication. \r

The NIMH recommends that people with serious mental illnesses receive professional treatment and follow up visits every 3 months to assess progress. Treatment often includes psychotherapy and medications to control the symptoms. \r

People with certain mental health conditions, especially those who require hospitalization for mental health care or psychiatric services such as counseling, intensive outpatient treatments or hospitalizations, should see their doctors regularly throughout life so they receive appropriate care. For example, someone with bipolar disorder or schizophrenia may benefit from regular medical evaluation, psychological testing and counseling, and behavioral therapy to keep them on track. If you believe you may be experiencing a depressive episode or a psychotic disorder, talk to your doctor about the best course of action. You might want to check out our article on ways to reduce stress in your daily life. \r

How Is Depression Different From Other Illnesses? A number of different factors contribute to the severity and impact of depression, including genetic predisposition, biological processes, environmental factors and lifestyle choices. For example, people who develop depression frequently report feeling sad or hopeless, having thoughts of death or harming self or others, feeling helpless or helpless. This kind of thinking seems to occur during times of intense stress, such as when jobs and relationships are difficult to maintain, or when finances become difficult. It has been suggested by some experts that depressed individuals may be less responsive to the social cues used to promote positive emotions like laughter and smiles, and that this may lead to their feelings of being "stuck" or "down."\r

People who take part in physical activity may find that they cannot function effectively if they feel down and sad.

query: Q: what is psychotherapy?\nA:
answer1: Psychotherapy, like any other form of therapy, is a process where we try to help people with problems or stresses and emotions. This includes helping them discover their deepest emotional needs. It also helps them learn how to manage those needs so that they may feel better in the long run. Some of these include learning new skills, building relationships with others, improving self-esteem and confidence, increasing life satisfaction, making changes in life, and reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety. Q: Why would someone consider having treatment for mental health issues?\nA: There are many reasons for this - as well as the fact that it's often much cheaper than using traditional medical treatments, such as prescription drugs, which can be expensive. Also, because it focuses on helping people develop healthy ways of thinking about themselves and the world, rather than treating specific illness or disorders, it tends to focus more on finding solutions to problems instead of just 'fixing' the problem at hand (which is usually unsuccessful). It's also much easier to get involved in - you don't have to find a counsellor who has an actual training in psychology or psychiatry or even a doctor in your area to refer you to a therapist. Q: What is psychodynamic psychotherapies like?\nA: These are therapies aimed at addressing deeper aspects of our inner lives. They're based on beliefs and attitudes held by our ancestors and family members from the past, which may not always reflect our current views. For instance, a person may believe that all pain is caused by bad karma (e.g., bad thoughts), but then decide that some of her own experiences and feelings were just part of life's ups and downs. Similarly, a person may feel very sad after a recent bereavement but think she feels great now, yet later say that she's still feeling down and depressed. In addition, a person may hold different values from those held by society and from his parents/teachers. That doesn't mean he'll necessarily become "better" if he goes through the same thing again, but will simply bring out new values of his own. The most effective way to deal with these issues is to come up with alternative perspectives. So, for example, if someone believes that all good things happen because of God, he might start working towards becoming a Christian priest, since it's believed to be something everyone should do. Another approach involves understanding the causes of our problems and trying to change them before they cause us harm or damage ourselves or others. Q: Are there any

A therapy that helps people live with and understand their emotions. Psychotherapy involves helping the person cope with feelings, thoughts and behaviors by changing them, using positive reinforcement techniques, and talking about difficult issues. Some of these may include:

Relaxing and focusing on the present moment

Embracing your strengths rather than suppressing your weaknesses

Learning to accept yourself as you are and learn to value yourself for who you really are

Treating problems in a constructive manner rather than blaming others or trying to fix things at your own expense

Finding ways to let go of anger and hurtful feelings

Recognizing when something triggers painful memories

Getting help from others if necessary

Having someone else (usually a parent, spouse, friend) come into your life to support you through times of difficulty

Knowing how to manage feelings safely and appropriately

Understanding how to use different coping skills (e.g., self-care, relaxation, sleep, exercise, etc.) and what they mean in everyday life

In addition to providing emotional support, therapy can also help prevent symptoms of depression, such as low moods, anxiety, insomnia, loss of interest in activities, lack of energy, poor concentration, and so forth. The treatment process uses lots of cognitive behavioral strategies and a variety of behavioral interventions. For example, CBT can be used to teach people to:


Understand their feelings

Know which emotions are most important and why

Learn new skills to deal with stressful situations

Identify unhealthy habits such as drinking excessively, smoking, overusing certain medications, overeating, being too hard on themselves, or avoiding social events

Develop healthier eating habits and reduce stress

Plan ahead, and stick to it

Think carefully before doing anything that might trigger an emotion

Create healthy routines that keep you happy

Find ways to give and receive positive feedback and encouragement

Use tools to overcome resistance to change or challenge your beliefs

Participate in peer groups or other supportive environments.

Family therapy, which focuses on relationships between parents and children, as well as parenting behavior

Interpersonal dynamics, including relationship dynamics between spouses and partners, children and siblings

"Psychology can be used for everything from making friends with someone who has difficulty seeing themselves as others see them (like a person whose parents think they're fat) to treating someone who may have a serious disease like cancer," says Dr. Michael Lescroart, PsyD, a registered psychologist who specializes in psychopharmacological treatments. \r

"In psychotherapy, there isn't really any one question that gets answered, just more questions: "What am I afraid of?" "Is there something wrong with me?" Psychotherapy has different forms to suit your needs. Some therapists will use psychoanalysis in their treatments or other types of counselling as an adjunct for the treatment itself. Other methods include cognitive behavioural therapy, mindfulness-based stress reduction, interpersonal skills training and talk therapy. Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which the body attacks itself. It causes inflammation of a part of your brain called the spinal cord, and also can affect other parts of your body, such as muscles or nerves. The most common type of MS is relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS). You may have either primary MS (primary progressive MS) or secondary MS (secondary progressive MS), but both types are not usually diagnosed together because they're treated differently. For more information about how to diagnose multiple sclerosis, read "How Is Multiple Sclerosis Diagnosed?"

What is the treatment for MS?\nA: There's no cure for MS; you need to take medication. Some people with MS use medicines called steroids. Other people just live with their illness and don't get any help from medications at all. Read more about managing MS symptoms and treatments.

Can I get pregnant after having MS?\nA: No. However, if you have high levels of certain hormones, including progesterone, the condition known as amenorrhea can develop. If this happens during pregnancy, contact your doctor right away so that he/she can perform testing to make sure there aren't complications. Also, ask your doctor about getting tested for HIV. You could be exposed to HIV through blood transfusion or sex during pregnancy. If HIV is detected while you're pregnant, it doesn't mean you should stop taking medications to treat your MS. It only means you should try to avoid risky sexual practices until you've had several prenatal visits. For more information, see our page on STDs.

query: Q: How to manage multiple sclerosis?\nA:
answer1:
There are a number of methods. For one, you can try and identify the best therapies for your particular condition (including MS), then decide which would be most appropriate and appropriate to follow. If treatment is not working, you could use medication to reduce symptoms or other techniques. The same approach applies if there's no other treatment option available. And, again, remember that any therapy will help some people with MS, but it may also cause side effects. Many medications have been shown in studies to cause significant adverse reactions and even death in patients who take them for long periods of time, so carefully consider whether the benefits outweigh the risks. Also, there are many medical conditions that can lead to serious problems with the immune system; therefore, there are a variety of vaccines available to protect against these diseases.

Q: Is there anything else I should know about my illness?\nA: When someone has MS, they often experience worsening of their health over time, especially as their body continues to lose its ability to regulate itself and fight infections. This is known as autoimmunity, an autoimmune disease that occurs when healthy cells attack and destroy the healthy ones around them. Autoimmune disorders such as MS can last years before starting to improve. So you might feel like everything just seems OK until one day everything changes completely -- or worse. It's important to keep up to date on what's happening and to get regular tests to see if your progress is slowing down. Remember to always stay out of bed if you've had pain or fever for more than four weeks. And remember that being in remission isn't permanent. Some people go back into a chronic state once their disease has gone into remission, but this usually only lasts for several months. Be sure to talk to your doctor and your family members regularly about your status and your progress.
answer2:
There are a variety of strategies, including medications and physical therapy. For those who have symptoms that prevent them from working or learning well, the best way is to try using computer programs that help people with MS control their movements. Many of these programs use video games as a substitute for tasks. Others include exercise and movement training. However, it's important to make sure you're doing everything you can to maintain good health while managing your disease. See our page on managing multiple sclerosis.

Q: I'm taking medication to treat my pain. Is there any reason we should stop taking this medicine? \nA: Doctors don't recommend stopping all medications because they might lead to complications or side effects. If you continue to take medication for chronic conditions such as MS, talk with your doctor about how you may need to change your dose or adjust the timing. A recent study found that although many drugs used to treat chronic illnesses also affect blood pressure, no other drug has been shown to cause a significant rise in blood pressure above normal levels without raising the risk of heart attacks and strokes. It's not clear why some medicines are more effective than others when taken in combination. Some medications used for treating MS increase the risk of blood clots and stroke by making people more vulnerable to heart attack and stroke.

Q: Can I keep taking the same anti-viral medicine during treatment for my MS? What if I get sick after being prescribed an anti-viral medication? \nA: Yes. People can take anti-virals for up to five years before becoming too ill to benefit from the treatment. They can be started at lower doses (e.g., 1 mg) before you become very ill. If you do start treatment with an HIV/AIDS medication, you must continue taking it until you've had two full months without signs or symptoms of infection. You must follow the instructions carefully in order to avoid serious harm. Read more about stopping and starting antiretrovirals.

Q: When am I supposed to see my doctor about my current flare-ups? Should I call ahead to let her know what's going on?\nA: Your doctor will tell you when she thinks it's time to schedule a visit so that you won't feel rushed into seeing your doctor. This could be just before your next headache or even weeks before your next relapse. And you probably want to plan your visit out thoroughly -- make appointments for tests, follow-up appointments, and follow-up phone calls. Check the American
answer3:
It is a disease where symptoms are severe enough that you will have to go into physical therapy or medication. You may be able to get some relief from medication, but the worst part for MS sufferers is finding someone who can help you as you experience these symptoms and they don't know how to deal with them. Your doctor may recommend that you see a therapist. A lot of people find it hard to tell others about their condition because of social stigma associated with MS. However, if you feel comfortable talking about this, ask your health care provider what helps you cope when MS affects everyday life.

Q: Can I still work while having MS?

A: Yes, although there is not much research on whether working with MS affects people's ability to do so. Some studies suggest that patients working at home for long periods of time can develop serious problems such as vision impairment and hearing loss. If you want to continue your career, keep in mind that you'll need to take breaks during which you won't be able to work. Also, consider moving to another location. Moving could make it harder to stay active.

Q: How do I become more aware of my MS symptoms?

A: You should talk to your doctor about ways to increase awareness and understanding of your disease. Talk to your caregiver, friends, family members, coworkers, etc. to build trust and understand one another better. When you get out of bed, walk around town and be active, you'll notice subtle changes in your body. Be sure to keep an eye out for the signs and symptoms of MS such as fatigue, weakness, blurred vision, muscle pain, numbness and tingling (reduced sensation).

Q: What's the best way to manage my disability?

A: As much as possible, try to avoid activities that involve using your hands or feet. Many people suffer from cognitive decline when left too long without assistance and there are many alternatives for helping you with daily tasks. For example, take walks in parks, play sports, use wheelchairs, watch movies on DVD player or participate in other forms of leisure activity. The key thing is that each person takes responsibility for taking care of themselves and doing things that improve their quality of life and reduce their burden on others.
answer4: There is no single treatment that will solve all of the MS symptoms, but there are some things you can do. For instance, keep a close watch on your immune system. You have about 12-15 different kinds of autoimmune disease and if you don't get it under control then they could go from being manageable to life threatening. Other than that, I am sure everyone has heard about the common cold, how it's caused by your body making too many antibodies in response to viruses, bacteria etc. This is also an issue with MS. Try to avoid having sex or getting food at certain times when you may be more sensitive to the virus. Also make sure to clean up after yourself as often as possible. The only thing you should not do is take any kind of medication during this time. A number of people report having been diagnosed with MS who were never actually sick. They had just taken the wrong drug and became ill. When you think about it, this makes sense. It appears that the immune system is very good at fighting off infections, but it sometimes gets out of whack. If you do feel like going into a doctor for help, you may want to bring along a friend who knows what she/he is talking about. If you aren't feeling well you can always call the National Multiple Sclerosis Society 24 hours a day, 7 days a week at 1-800-823-0677. \nI2\ BACK TO TOP

The best way is to keep the disease under control with daily exercise. But in some cases, you may need medical treatment. Aspirin and acetaminophen can help you feel better if it's not enough. If your symptoms are getting worse, see a doctor.

Q: How do I take vitamin D supplements?

A: Taking the right type of vitamin D is essential for maintaining good health. A study conducted by the National Institutes of Health found that taking a supplement containing 400 IU of vitamin D a day could reduce risk of stroke from 35 percent to 17 percent; decrease your risk of death from cardiovascular causes from 21 percent to 10 percent; and reduce heart attack rates from 6 percent to 1 percent. To get more vitamin D, eat foods rich in vitamin D such as milk, eggs, green leafy vegetables, oily fish, fortified cereals and soups, and fortified foods like milk, yogurt and fortified juices. For adults aged 50 to 70 years, the Institute of Medicine recommends 600 International Units (IU) of vitamin D each day. Adults over 70 should take two 500-unit doses of vitamin D every other week.

Q: What happens when my blood levels of vitamin K exceed 30 nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL)?

A: Your body produces too little of this vitamin when your diet contains plenty of calcium. So before you start taking a prescription drug or another form of vitamin K supplement, check with your doctor. Some drugs contain vitamin K while others don't. Vitamin K deficiency has been linked to heart failure, high cholesterol, osteoporosis, memory loss, arthritis, depression, seizures, diabetes, Parkinson's disease, migraines, kidney stones, blood clots and nerve damage. In addition to increased risks, taking vitamin K often results in side effects including headache, fatigue, pain, rash, bone pain, weight gain and acne. Talk to your doctor about whether your medications contain vitamin K.

Q: Why doesn't everyone get enough iron?

A: Iron helps our bodies absorb water, which makes us stronger. Too much iron in your system can cause anemia. Even moderate amounts can increase your risk of developing liver cancer, heart disease and certain cancers, including breast, lung and colon cancer. To prevent these diseases and illnesses, talk to your doctor about how many servings of fruits and vegetables and whole grains your family eats each day. Eating more red meat and dairy products may also raise your iron intake. Ask your doctor about any dietary changes
answer6:
The key is not only to keep a consistent and accurate record of your symptoms, but also to stay vigilant about the causes. There are many factors that may make MS worse or better, such as inflammation or infection. It's important to use an effective treatment strategy at all times and to learn what medications work best for you based on your individual case.

What should I do if I have persistent low back pain (spinal stenosis)?\nA: Spinal stenosis can be very frustrating because it can prevent proper functioning in some people. In addition to using an ergonomic chair to support your spine, it's important to watch out for other potential causes of spinal stenosis, such as arthritis, trauma, surgery or degenerative disc disease (such as diabetes). If you suspect spinal stenosis, speak with your health care provider so he or she can examine your spine to identify any possible root cause. Treatment options include medication and physical therapy.

How often should I take my medications?\nA: Your doctor will want to monitor how your body responds to different medications. You can safely use different types of medicines at the same time‚Äîfor example, you could start taking one medicine and then switch back when you're feeling well again. Also, even though there are different drugs available over-the-counter (OTC) and prescription (PCP) medications, they usually interact differently; thus, it's critical to know which medications you need to be careful when using them together. For instance, if you need to stop taking an OTC drug to treat a medical condition, it might be helpful to switch back to a PCP medication first to allow your body to adapt to the change.
